_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the polyurethane foam manufacturing system. The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of a regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Carpenter Co. - Riverside facility maintains and operates a process system comprised of Methyl Formate and Toluene Diisocyanate, 80:20 TDI blend (80 wt% 2,4 TDI and 20 wt% 2,6 TDI) hereby referred to as TDI. Not including unloading of the regulated chemicals Methyl Formate and TDI to their respective storage tanks,there is one process these regulated chemical are involved in.



Polyurethane Foam Manufacturing Process: Equipment for the regulated substances involved in the manufacturing of polyurethane foam include: four 55,000 gallon TDI storage tanks, two 12,500 gallon TDI metering tanks, one 10,000 gallon Methyl Formate storage tank, one Methyl Formate booster pump, one Methyl Formate pump metering skid, two heat exchangers, and multiple TDI transfer pumps. Both Methyl Formate and TDI are individually piped and do not come into contact with one another until they meet at the mixing head where the foam is poured. Additionally, there can be up to four approximately 23,700 gallon (each) TDI railcars stored onsite. Details of the inventory calculation can be found in the Process Safety Information (PSI) section of the Compliance Workbook.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP/CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated toxic chemical involved in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process (TDI). The results can be found in the

Hazard Assessment documentation.



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP/CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated toxic chemical involved in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process (TDI). The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.



Risk Considerations:

Although both the handling of Methyl Formate and TDI and the production of polyurethane foam have inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a Methyl Formate and/or TDI release. The facility utilizes pressure relief valves, manual and automated shutoffs, and emergency shutdown systems.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of the Prevention Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of Methyl Formate and TDI. Prevention elements for each program are listed in Table 1 below.



List of Prevention Program Elements:

- Process Safety Information

- Process Hazard Analysis

- Operating Procedures

- Training

- Mechanical Integrity

- Management of Change

- Pre-Startup Safety Review

- Compliance Audits

- Incident Investiga

tion

- Employee Participation

- Hot Work Permit

- Contractor



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no EPA RMP/CalARP-applicable releases of TDI at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. The facility began storing methyl formate above the threshold quantity on April 25, 2013.  There have been no EPA RMP/CalARP-applicable releases of Methyl Formate at the facility since that time.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:



The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.



During the March 2016 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team. General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of either Methyl Formate or TDI were addressed. The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.



The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.



The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.



For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply

1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

2) Major hazards identified;

3) Process controls in use;

4) Mitigation systems in use;

5) Monitoring and detection systems in use;

and,

6) Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PA



The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed.



The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted on January 27, 2018 and included the major equipment of the process.



Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.6 (l) and 2745.7 (q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of Methyl Formate or TDI were addressed by the PHA.



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP/CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated flammable substance involved in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process (Methyl Formate). The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP/CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the regulated flammable substance involved in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process (Methyl Formate). The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 as well as all the required state and local agencies in case of an emergency. Contact phone numbers are listed in the Incident Investigation section of the facility's program binder. Carpenter Co. - Riverside will coordinate with local Fire Department and their privately contracted Emergency Environmental Response provider "CB&I, Inc." in the event of an emergency due to an uncontrolled release of a regulated hazardous substance. The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety a

re listed as recommendations in the March 2016 PHA Report. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed in a timely manner and all corrective actions taken will be recorded in the Action Tracking Log that can be found in Appendix A of CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.
